question:
(a) identify specimens A, B, C, D, and E

          

(b) name one source of each of specimens A, B, C, D, and E

(c) Name a small farm machine used for the production of specimen B.

(d) Name the stimulant obtained from specirmen E.

(e) State two uses each of specimens A and B.

(f) Name the process by which specimen A is made fit for consumpion.
answer:
(a) ldentification of Specimens:

  • A- Powdered milk or liquid milk/milk
  • B- Palm Oil
  • C- A piece of white cotton cloth or white cloth
  • D - A small piece of leather
  • E - A stick of cigarette

(b) Sources of each of the specimens:

  • A- From numinant animals, livestock, sheep or goat and cattle/mammal or cow mummy
  • B - Oil palm tree / fruit / bunch/oil palm:
  • C - Cotton lint / plant / bowl / fiber / wool;
  • D - Cattle or sheep or goat skin l animal skin / Ruminant skin;
  • E - tobacco plant/leaves:

(c) Name of small farm machine used for the production of specimen B is hydraulic press/hard press

(d) The name of stimulant from the source of specimen E is Nicotine

(e) Uses of Specimens A and B

(i) Milk:

  • Source of protein in food,
  • raising foster calves, lambs or children,
  • preparation of baby food,
  • supply of minerals to Iivestock,
  • used as extender in Artificial Insemination practices,
  • used in the preparation of dairy products e.g. butter cheese, yogurt.

(ii) Palm oil:

  • For lubrication or prevent rust;
  • used for preparing food.
  • Also used for making soap or cooking;
  • used for making body cream or lotion;
  • used for the production of margarine;
  • used in Iivestock feed
  • used as fuel for making fire.
  • It is also medicinal;
  • Also used in making of candles

(f) The process by which specimen A is made fit for consumption is through Pasteurization.

question:
(a) ldentify specimens F, G, H, and, I

         

(b) State three factors that determine the quality of specimen F

(c) State six effects of specimen G on the soil.

(d) State four effects of specimen I on the soil.
answer:
(a) ldentification of Specimens

  • F: poultry dropping/manure;
  • G- Cow dung / manure;
  • H- N.P.K. (15.15.15) fertilizer/compound;
  • I - Limestone / CaCo,

(b) Factors that determine the quality of Specimen F-

  • type of management of animals in use e.g. deep litter, battery cage, free-range, semi-intensive
  • type of feed given to animals
  • age of animals
  • state of health of the animals
  • stage of decomposition of specimen / time / period

(c) Effects of Specimen G on the soil;

  • add the primary nutrients such as nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium to the soil. It also improves soil fertility;

  • helps in binding the particles of soil together

  • improves the soil aeration and porosity

  • improves the rate of water percolation in fine-textured soils;

  • improves the rate of water retention in coarse-textured soils;

  • increases the population of soil microbes;

  • encourages microbial decomposition in the soil;

  • addition of organic matter to the soil;

  • Increases crop yield.

(d) effects of limestone (Specimen l) on the soil;

  • neutralizes the soil acidity or pH;
  • adds calcium to the soil;
  • improves the soil structure;
  • encourages microbial decomposition in the soil,
  • increases nutrients availability/ increases soil fertility.

question:
(a) ldentify specimen J, K, and L

      

(b) State the method of propagation of specimens J and L.

(c) (i) Name the principal food nutrients for livestock Contained in specimens J, K and L
(ii) State the form(s) of preserving specimens J and K

(d) State the importance of specimen J apart from its food value.

(e) State three importance of specimen L.
answer:
(a) ldentification of Specimens:

  • Specimen J - Guinea grass
  • K - Elephant grass / giant star grass
  • L - Stylo Sylosanthes gracilis) or cowpea or groundnut plants / leaves.

(b) Propagation of Specimens J and L

  • Specimen J- it is propagated by seeds; - tillers or rooted clumps/ vegetative propagation
  • Specimen L- propagated by seeds. - Stem cuttings / vegetative.

(c)(i) Principal food nutrients for livestock contained in Specimens:

  • Specimen J- Carbohydrates
  • K- carboyhydrates
  • L- (plant) protein

(ii) Forms of preserving Specimens J and K

  • Specimen J- as Silage; hay;
  • Specimen K- as silage, as hay:

(d) Importance or Specimen J (guinea grass) apart from its food value;

  • the dried stems if woven together can be made into fences, doormats and thatching of roof or bedding material.
  • It can be Used as or for mulching litter/mulching.
  • It is used as fuel also.

(e) Importance of stylo/groundnut/cowpea -(Specimen L);

  • lt helps check soil erosion;
  • It also helps in nitrogen fixation in the soil;
  • It can be ploughed in as green manure.
  • It improves soil fertility
  • Cowpea is used in livestock feeding and also act as a cover crop

question:
(a) ldentify specimens M, N, O, and P

         

(b) State three uses each of specimens M, N, and O.

(c) State one advantage each of using specimens M and N.

(d) State two disadvantages of using specimen P in brooding of chicks.
answer:
a) ldentification of Specimens:

  • M- chicks' water fountain/drinker/water
  • N - wooden feed trough / feeding trough / feeder
  • O - egg candler
  • P- lantern/bush lamp/lamp

(b) Use of Specimens M, N, and O.

Chicks' water fountain;

  • water is poured into the container and then covered with the base,
  • the container is turned upside down so that water drips out of a small opening into the cover which serves as the base
  • it is placed on the floor of deep-litter house or on a raised platform
  • the chicks gather around the trough to drink water from the base.

Wooden feed trough;

  • Feed is poured directly into the wooden trough and spread inside.
  • Trough should be half-filled to avoid wastages resulting from scratching by chicks when feeding
  • Trough is re-filled regularly as the content diminishes.
  • It is usually placed On the floor of deep-litter house.

Egg Candler:

  • The egg is placed in a hole on the candler, and the light is switched on to illuminate the egg thus, revealing the egg's content particularly the developing embryo.,
  • the egg candler is usually used during or before incubation to determine the fertility of eggs.

(c) Advantages of using Specimens M and N:

Specimen M Chicks' water fountain;

  • The water inside the trough cannot be easily contaminated by the chicks' droppings.,
  • The system is cheap,
  • is self-regulating, thus avoiding water wastage.

Specimen N Wooden feed trough:

  • It is easy to construct
  • cheap to construct,
  • easy to maintain;
  • reduces feed wastage:
  • reduces feed contamination.

(d) Disadvantages of using Specimen P - lantern.;

  • It is not very effective since few chicks can be taken care of,
  • the fumes are unhealthy to chicks: and can cause fire disaster.,
  • chicks can get burnt when they jump on top of the lantern
